thread.title: Boil-water order canceled for east bank of New Orleans
thread.title_full: Boil-water order canceled for east bank of New Orleans | NOLA.com

author: NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Boil-water order canceled for east bank of New Orleans
text:
The Sewerage & Water Board of New Orleans, in consultation with the state Department of Health and Hospitals, has canceled the precautionary boil-water advisory for residents and businesses on the east bank of New Orleans after bacteriological tests confirmed that water in the area is safe to drink and can be used normally for personal needs.
Customers are advised to flush their internal and external plumbing by running water through their system.
"We are pleased that the tests proved negative and that we can cancel the boil water advisory at this time," SWB Executive Director Cedric Grant said in a statement released early Friday (Sept. 25). We issued the advisory in the best interest of our customers and with an abundance of caution to ensure their health and safety. I commend the fast and professional work by SWB employees from several departments and the excellent cooperation of DHH officials."
The order was issued Wednesday night electrical service was interrupted at the Carrollton water treatment plant causing two of four active pumps to briefly shut down, resulting in a drop in pressure in the city's network of water pipes.
When the pressure in the system drops below 15 pounds per square inch, contaminated groundwater can begin to penetrate leaking pipes and commingle with treated water on its way to houses and businesses. Pressure in parts of the system dropped as low as 6 psi.
Water samples were taken for testing from about 90 sites around the city. It takes about 24 hours to complete the tests.
This was the 10 th time in the past five years that the Sewerage & Water Board has issued a boil-water advisory. City officials say they are pursuing changes in the system to reduce future problems.
